market_summary: Sharp selloff Feb 12: SPY -1.65%, QQQ -2.19%, DIA -1.37%; Mag 7 tech stocks wiped out $500B market cap as memory chip shortage threatens margins
Micron (MU) surging +8.8% over 10 days despite volatility; analysts positive on AI memory supercycle and structural demand despite commodity multiple
Bitcoin down -13% to $65.3K; Energy sector under pressure with XOM -2.4%; gold (GLD) -2.85%; crypto and commodities broadly weak

thesis: AI memory supercycle: MU revenue +49% YoY to $37.4B FY25, gross margin expansion to 39.8% from 22.4%, operating margin 27.1% vs 7.1% prior year—structural shift from commodity cyclicality to AI-driven demand

Positioning ahead of Mag 7 capex: Tech giants planning $680B AI infrastructure spend in 2026; memory shortage narrative emerging as Cisco warned on margin pressure—MU uniquely exposed as memory supplier bottleneck

Strong momentum + valuation disconnect: Stock up 8.8% in 10 days despite sector selloff; trading 16x P/E vs 46x NVDA, 25x MSFT—analysts highlight 'commodity multiple despite structural AI growth'; free cash flow inflection with $1.68B FCF (vs -$6B FY23)
risks: Memory cycle volatility: Historical boom-bust pattern; FY23 posted -$5.8B net loss when cycle turned—investors fear repeat despite AI narrative
Concentration risk: Heavy exposure to Mag 7 capex spending; if tech giants slow AI infrastructure build (like MSFT downgrade concerns), MU revenue hits immediately
Valuation stretched on absolute basis: $415 price represents 3.7x sales vs 2.5x book; if memory shortage narrative fails or AI capex disappoints, momentum reverses sharply
falsifiable_checks: MU quarterly earnings (next: Q2 FY26 likely March 2026): Revenue growth >15% QoQ, gross margin sustained >38%, guidance confirms memory shortage persisting into H2 2026
Mag 7 capex execution: Track MSFT/META/GOOGL quarterly capex disclosures through Q1 2026—if aggregate AI infrastructure spend decelerates below $150B quarterly run rate, thesis weakens
trade_of_the_day.why_now: Market pricing in tech weakness creates entry: Feb 12 selloff took AAPL -5.1%, NVDA -3.3%, META -3.0% on memory shortage fears, yet MU relatively outperformed at -1.6% intraday. Memory shortage is a supply bottleneck that benefits MU as the critical infrastructure provider. Wall Street just caught on—Goldman highlighted 7 memory stocks, analyst articles flooding in Feb 11-12 on 'memory supercycle' thesis. Positioning before March quarter earnings when guidance will likely confirm structural tightness lasting 6-18 months as AI accelerator deployments ramp.
